3:34 correction
It's the shutter speed that changes if the motion blur occurs or not. If a camera is shooting a 5 fps but the shutter speed is significantly high there will be no motion blur. But even a 60 fps video will have motion blur if the shutter speed is low. The shutter speed changes based on the light in the surroundings. So the shutter speed is high in bright sunlight as it dosent need much light for a frame whereas the shutter speed will be low in low light as it needs more light to produce a clear image.

Video is a sequence of pictures that are similar to each other that when switched fast enough, will create an illusion that it is moving, but it is actually pictures that is switched super fast and those pictures we call frames. I just find this statement amusing.
"If frame rates get higher and higher, you wind up with an image that can actually cause headaches."

Also, 4:15 :
Those pictures aren't actually being delivered at thousands of FPS. Especially in 2011, you'd be lucky if the program was delivering more than 24fps. Motion blur is actually an artifact of our eyes remembering the photons that were there previously (I'm kinda bumbling up the explanation, but that's the gist). We add artificial motion blur because images are actually showing up too slow for that effect to take place. The reason people feel ill while watching higher FPS content is simply the fact that people aren't used to it. Especially with older audiences, because they don't consume much YT content (which has had 60fps for years now) and they don't play modern games where the standard has become 60fps and now being pushed this very year to 120fps! That's nothing to say about the 240hz or 360hz monitors that are out now for PC titles.

I know this is an old video but I just want to point out that what you said about motion blur and dizziness from high frame rates isn't entirely correct

When your eyes track a fast-moving object in real life, light from the same parts of that object hits the same part of the retina, thus giving the retina that 1/15th of a second it needs to see a clear image. On the other hand, if you see a fast moving object but don't track it with your eyes, light coming off of it is going to move across different parts of your retina without giving it that 1/15th of a second to see a clear image, which results in motion blur

The problem with motion sickness is not caused because the "picture is too clear" in HFR content. In fact, the higher the frame rate, the more closely it'll resemble reality because it allows our eyes to more naturally track or not track objects. That means we might still see the natural motion blur caused by our retinas even if there is none in the video. The cause of motion sickness is actually the camera movement. Because movement is so smooth and realistic in HFR content, some people who easily get motion sick misinterpret camera movement from the screen as real movement, and when that doesn't match up with the signals coming from the vestibular system, their brain gets confused by those mixed signals and the result is motion sickness

I feel like you explained this poorly. Yes, our eyes don't see in frames per second. And although you didn't mention it specifically, I got the feeling you hinted at how there are diminishing returns as you get a higher framerate. Recently I switched from a 60 Hz monitor to a 144 Hz monitor and the difference is night and day. I find it hard to play games on 60 Hz anymore. At my college for our eSports program, we use 240 Hz monitors, and the difference is still definitely noticeable for me, but not as pronounced. This isn't completely relevant, but it's just my background with experiencing greater than 60 fps, which is the standard for monitors (at least in the US, it might be 50 in other parts of the world, but I don't know for sure).


When you say we start to get headaches from higher framerates (you mentioned 1000 fps), that would be what it is recorded at (well, sort of. But for simplicity's sake and keeping this readable, lets just assume that it is being recorded at 1000 fps). The reason that would give people headaches is because each of those 1000 frames is more like a picture, but it can't display the full 1000 frames per second. That would depend on the monitor or TV you use. If you record something at 30 frames per second, then each of those frames is actually in a way, an average of everything that happened in 1/30th of a second. That is motion blur. If you then play it back at 30 frames per second, then it would look relatively smooth. But if you were to record it in 1000 fps and play it back in real time at 30 frames per second (skipping frames so that it would play back in real time) it would look much choppier; the frame would only have been an average of the last 1/1000 of a second. It would essentially have no motion blur. But if you would display the 1000 fps video on display that could display 1000 fps, (a 1000 Hz display) then it would look like a super smooth video.

Having used a 200Hz monitor an extensive amount, I have found that all high refresh rate content I have viewed has always looked much more fluid and far less headache inducing than content at lower frame rates. Having a high refresh rate doesn't mean that objects move quicker on the screen. It means that their location is updated more often, but in smaller increments, so things look more fluid.

I always game with motion blur turned off, and some friends have said that it originally felt as though motion blur was turned on when using a high refresh rate. This is probably because your eye will see less of a difference between what's on screen and looking at things in real life, and therefore your brain can input its own motion blur as it would if you weren't looking at a monitor.

Someone didn't do their research.... no TV program or movie is running at 1000 frames per second, and even if there was one, no commercially available TV is capable of showing 1000 frames per second, a good bunch of TVs can't actually show more than 30 images per second, most can show up to 60 per second but anything that claims 400hz or 1000hz... its just a marketing gimmick, those TVs just have post processing added onto the image between receiving it from the source and actually outputting it to the TV screen.
Headaches from high frame rate video are not actually directly caused by the frame rate at all, the high frame rate just makes camera movement more visible so of course, if the camera isn't held steadily enough you will see that and thats what causes the headache. and its nothing to do with blur or no blur either, blur happens due to persistence of vision and your eyes still apply it whether its an image on a screen or a real object.

so finally we have millions of cells firing up randomly/interlaced creating a random FPS that averages around 500 FPS~ that is why when you get used to 75+Hz setting on your PC CRT and go back to 60Hz (Hz and FPS are the same) you see bullets becoming jittery and the camera moving is jittery also and you get head aches! the best is about 85Hz where your mind has enough FPS to work with but to an excessive amount! Many thing wrong in this video... First of all LCD monitors and TV blurs out the transitions between the frames so 60fps looks ok but if you look at the same frame rate on a good old CRT tv/monitor 60fps looks not half as smooth and you need 100fps to make it look similary smooth. Second the eye is actually very much like a camera in many ways and the eye can see much faster movement in bright light then in dim low light conditions, the eye have actually have a sort of varying shutter speed and it even has gain control with similar problems with noise as a camera in low light condition... And no high frame-rates do not give you a headache (or the real world would give you a constant one with its practically infinite frame-rate). What gives people headaches is flickering images in around 50-60hz like good old CRT monitors and TV`s with to low hz...

Ummm... I think that's not right. Your hand popping up everywhere in the video isn't due to a high frame rate of the camera, but a high shutter speed. If you think of each frame of video like the exposure of a picture, when it's really bright, the shutter speed is increased, and the time that the shutter remains open decreases. Because of this high shutter speed, there is no blur.

How could Vsauce make a such a big mistake? First thing, yes I agree that a camera can pick up a lot more FPS than the human eye. That's why you can see some video in extreme slow motion without any blurr.

But capturing something with a camera in 1000 FPS and then play it from a monitor in normal speed doesn't mean you can catch up the 1000 FPS because the camera did. We only benefit from this when we set it to slow motion. Capturing something in 1000 FPS won't do anything if you watch it in normal speed. The downside with this would be screen tearing.

The most surprised thing is that he says 30 FPS is the minimum to get the normal experience. If you can't see that the ball is skipping at 30 FPS or that you cannot see a difference between 30 FPS and higher, than there's something wrong with you.

I don't know what the max FPS the human eye can see, but it's surely over 30 FPS without a doubt. It's not even a discussion.

And for the people that will say "But this video is in 24 FPS"
No it's not. Standard Youtube videos is 30 FPS and there's a option to go higher if the OP sets it to it. If they of course use a camera that picks up higher FPS.

II think past 2:30 michal is a bit off, a bit mistaken. See the thing is, our sight does not work in a discrete digital domain, but rather in a continuous, analog domain. Instead of frame rate, or clock frequency, etc, there are response times, limits on rates of change in perception over time, persistence effects, etc. This is similar but fundamentally different. These "analog" effects cause the motion blur mentioned at 3:40. One of the ways you can easily tell the difference, at least with continuous vs discrete is with that hand example.

I think it has something to do with the eyeball and how the brain tells it to interpret that causes the blur. The human eye actually has a very tiny area that it focuses on at any given time, and since a TV screen is fully focused at a much larger area to compensate for changes of areas of interest on screen, you don't get the same blur you would from waving your hand in front of your face. Just as a jet flying by at mach 2 isn't blurry  at all if its flying by at a distance of 15 kilometers away, where you have a fuller view with which to focus. The pain some people have isn't a wives tale, but its not from just motion, its over exposure to light intensities. In fact, an outfit in Japan got in big trouble for making an animated movie with too much flashing light, because animation is an assortment of flasing black, and bright pannels and too much of it can overload sensitive neural signals, and even burn out your retina temporarily. Also, the single most effective way you can prevent the spread of germs is by washing your hands! Humans use hands to touch so many germy things, the occasions to wash them really help reduce the spread of germs. But I must admit, after 4 years, the "Ummm yeah" is still funny.

I'm surprised this video is still up after 3.5 years... it has some major problems (misunderstandings).  It really should be taken down Michael!

The first is at 2:30 when the classic data flow concepts of bandwidth and latency are mixed up.  For example you can have 500fps take 1 nanosecond to get from the eye to the brain.  That's high bandwidth and low latency.  You could also have 2fps take 2 seconds to get from the eye to the brain.  That's low bandwidth and high latency.  In this video bandwidth and latency are suggested to be the same.  They're not.

The second major problem is at 4:30 when it's said that really high frame rates make people sick because there is no motion blur.  This is one of those "snopes" wive's tales type of things.  Real life doesn't have motion blur.  Your brain adds it (Michael even says this fact in the video!)... same thing happens with high FPS video.  Your brain adds it.  Real life doesn't need motion blur externally applied, neither does high FPS video.  Most likely people are getting sick because they're seeing subtle movements and vibrations in the video but the inner ear which detects these movements is not also moving in sync with the video.  This nausea from vision being out of sync with physical movement is very common and well understood.

The reason why Dylan's camera can capture Michael's hand movement is because of the camera's shutter speed, not the frame rate. Low-end camcorders, when recording well-lit footage (in this case outside) tend to shoot at higher shutter speeds in order to expose correctly. The higher the shutter speed, the darker the footage, but that also means less blur.

Say there is a 1000 fps camera. Now say an object is moving so fast that when it moves in front of the camera it is only picked up on one frame. A person viewing the film will not be able to see it, so the human eye can perceive just under 1000 frames per second.
The maximum frame rate we can see on hi def is 24 fps, any more and you would need to add more of the same frame.

Great video; but I highly doubt higher frame rates cause headaches or dizziness. Low frame rates do that. Higher frame rates create smoother motions with less to no stuttering, particularly in fast action scenes where 24 or even 30 frames are proven inadequate and stuttering occurs. The more the frames the smoother slow motion can be depicted. A 900 fps video has 30 times smoother motion than a 30 fps video, so it can either be played up to 30 times slower or played normally, both with no stuttering. The lack of blurring does not create headaches, low frame stuttering does.

(4:14), TV broadcast doesn't go higher than 59.94 fps (NTSC standard).

You can obviously shoot footage at 100,000 fps or higher with special equipment (to be played back at <=59.94hz for slow motion) but with current day technology, projectors monitors and HDTV systems are limited to a maximum of 144hz,120hz,60hz respectively due to broadcast and interface standard limitations.

Your eyes would probably be able to tell the difference between 60hz and 120hz but as you start to go higher than that, the difference becomes less noticeable up to 240hz, where you won't be able to tell the difference compared to 1440hz, motion blur in the footage would make it impossible to notice any difference.

There is no benefit for video production companies to produce content that has higher frame rate than 60hz because you can't watch it on an HDTV.

You can certainly create and view content at a frame rate of 120hz at home if you happen to have like a $20000 camera(optional), a $2000 PC and a $400 24-inch 120hz LCD lying around. If you happen to purchase an HDTV with a "1000hz" logo, that is marketing bullshit. the LED back-light may flicker at 1000hz but the LCD panel in it cannot refresh higher than 120hz. (200hz is the technological limit for LCD panels).

I'd like to see a reference for the high frame rate headache claim, because the explanation sounds quite sketchy.  If the motion in the high frame rate recording is too fast for the eye to catch, the brain should simply add blur to the motion just like it does when seeing fast moving things in the real world.

The headache explanation sounded really flaky. If you had a display of infinite resolution and infinite frame rate, then ignoring eye focus depth and assuming that the camera itself didn't move, the video should look indistinguishable from the real world. The motion blur comes from persistence of vision and works the same way display or real life.

More likely, the headache is vertigo from camera movement. At a very high refresh rate the video looks real enough to make unexpected camera movements cause incongruence between vision, balance, and eye movement. With artificial motion blur added, the video behaves differently from the real world, as it breaks the association between eye tracking and perceived motion blur. Your brain can thus dismiss unexpected movement in it as just part of the video instead of your senses having gone mad.

4:06, the only time a TV show or movie is recorded at a frame rate higher than 60 is if the footage is going to be slowed down to a lower frame rate for a slow-motion effect, and most cameras, even high-end movie cameras, can't record faster than 60 fps. The only cameras that record up to and over 1000 fps are specially-designed slow-motion cameras like the Phantom Flex.

Furthermore, most consumer TVs and computer monitors have refresh rates below 240 Hz, so no, even if the program was being broadcast at 1000 fps, you wouldn't see it.

Early in television history it was found that frame rates less than 25 per second were noticed out of the corner of your eyes as a flicker. Since 1927, the standard frame rate for film has been 24 fps (frames per second). For TV the standard is 30 fps for NTSC (National
Television System Committee – the system used in North America, Japan and many other areas around the world), 25 fps for PAL (Phase Alternating Line – the system used in Europe, parts of Africa and SE Asia).

The Actual Frame rate Video can be played back at is limited to the refresh rate of a screen. Most modern flat screen/LCD/OLED/"whatever" TV (That's important) screens do not refresh faster than 48frames per second (fps), some higher end screens will refresh at 60fps.

The Refresh Rate is how quickly the screen can clear the previous image on screen, put up the next image, and repeat. This is normally expressed as Hz (Hertz), as in "cycles per second", a measure of frequency used in many other situations, including sound, light color, vibration. In short, Hz is a measure of oscillation, the undulation of a wave, the on/off of light, frames per second, the refresh rate of a screen.

Many newer computer monitors can refresh as fast as 240Hz or 240fps, maybe faster. This depends on the video card and how much information it has and can output to the monitor. Any faster is overkill, but for some applications you want the highest frame rate possible. However, Video games don't really need to be seen any faster than 60Hz/fps. There is no discernible change in game play quality past 48fps. 60fps is more for computational margin so the game can add in AI, physics, Special Effects, and so on. This is also true for TV, as higher frame rats can allow a TV to add back in Motion blur, 3D, and so on.

While it is possible to get eyestrain from no motion blur caused by recording the image at 1000fps or so. The bottom neck remains the screen replayed on and broadcast video is still limited to 30fps at most. This may change in the future. IT is not likely anyone will have to deal with more than 60fps outside of professional situations.

ordinary TV are 50 - 60 fps, about the A/C's frequency

I'm not going to go through all the comments to see if this was said. But the brain doesn't "add in" motion blur. It is genuine affect caused by lots of motion happening while the shutter is open. In the case of the eye the "shutter" is the chemicals in the rods and cones that take time to refresh after each photon of light is absorbed. They can only absorb so many photons per second and this gives the eye an equivalent of a shutter speed.

While you do add electrons to the device, not all devices will hold the electrons.  Methods of data storage include battery back up, imprinting, and various other methods.  A device that uses battery back up and similar will have extra weight from the data.  However, a data stored through imprinting and similar don't need a charge to maintain data, thus electrons won't be stored and the weight will have little to no change.
 
Just because electrons are added doesn't mean they stay on the device.

I think you made a error in the 1000 fps headache thing. The reason you get a headache, is because camaras at 24 fps have a lower shutter time, and get natural motion blur. With higher framerates. this time is much lower, so there is less blur. Now if the picture was actually displayed at 1000fps, there would be no problem, the images would blur on your eyeball as they are so similar, but your tv only displays 25 or 50 frames per second, so the ball "warps" as he otther frames are not seen.

You can tell it tho. In high res games, more frames will allow for a more natural motion blur, and thus a better experiance. However, most games (like bf3) have artifitial motion blur functionalities, and therefor its stupid to sacrifice image for framerate.

the reason you create moion blur is actually because the impact of a image lasts a short while, so your eyes are sending multiple hands, each in slighly different positions, creating a blur. No.  When you put digital data into a storage device, you're basically just writing onto it.  Although the content itself will have weight, it doesn't add physical weight to the device that is holding it.  Digital data is a bunch of zeros and ones.  Adding data is like turning various off switches on.  It is heavy in the sense that power is used for all the switches turned on, but it doesn't change the physical weight at all.

Actually, it isn't just the noobs.  It's people who also understand how the process works.  See, when it comes to live video, 60fps makes a huge difference simply because it is actual time.  However, most games aren't made with live video, but with digital or drawn design.  While 60fps can create fluid movement, it won't work well if the content isn't designed for it.  For example, an animation made for 15fps tends to be sloppy at 60fps.  That animation will need more frames to work at 60fps.

The way our internal frame-rate works is different from that of a camera. 
A camera takes a more instantaneous image every interval of a second. Our eyes see more of a time-lapse.
Every photon that hits your eye is recorded, but all of the things that are seen are put into one picture every 1/15 of a second or so. This is why you can notice differences in frame-rate in a video game or a movie well above 15 fps, even up to 120 fps in my experience. You see all those frames at once in one picture.

Actually, your brain does automatically blur the T.V screen. In my studies of most science in the past months, I have realized that an HD video or image is actually MORE CLEAR than real life. This is because your eyes aren't exactly perfect. Since the camera is carefully made, it has more than perfect vision. Since he image is so clear, your brain has to work harder to blur the image, but never completes the job because your brain would take longer to process the image and thought.

The problem is, even if the video is streaming at 1,000 frames per second, there's no way the television can show the video that fast. That's because of refresh rates. A 60 Hz HDTV or monitor can only DISPLAY a maximum 60 frames per second, because the screen only refreshes 60 times each second. Similarly, 120 Hz will display up to 120 frames per second. The input can be much higher, but the output will still be limited to the rate at which the screen is refreshing the displayed image.

The thing about motion blur and framerate isn't entirely true. It has to do with the shutterspeed of the film. Video at just 25fps (the standard in europe) can look jittery if the shutterspeed is high. 25fps is best recorded at a shutterspeed of 1/50th of a second, 30fps at 1/60th of a second and so on. It is however true that a higher framerate naturally needs a faster shutterspeed.

You're simply looking at a bunch of still pictures in a sequence that tricks the brain. Eyes don't see in frames per second, as Micheal explained in the video.

They're have the same principle. 

Shutter speed is the speed at which frames are captured, 

Frame rate is the speed they are shown. You can't have one without the other in video.

If you did, camera's would be like eyes, which they aren't. Eyes don't have a shutter speed, they don't see in individual frames, but a continuous stream of light that is interpreted by our brain. 

That's why eyes don't "record" at a framerate, and why we can't exactly measure how many fps they can perceive.

Well, yes, actually being there would give you the most lifelike representation of being there. The two questions you just asked, however, are not the same question. 

Our eyes cannot track fast moving objects, so instead the brain interprets the change in position with blurriness. Cameras, however are capable of tracking the movement with no blur at all. When we see the recording of something that normally would be blurry to us, but the camera didn't record that blur, it gives us a headache.

You can't have a frame rate of 30 frames per second if your shutter speed is slower than 1/30th of a second. That being said, you can't have a shutter speed of 1000fps if your shutter speed is slower than 1/1000th of a second.

It's the difference in the way the information is delivered. In real life the photons from the ball are received as a continuous flow. Our brain compensates tracking objects in this way by adding motion blur so we don't overload on info. While the tennis ball at 1000 fps on the HDTV is given not in a continuous flow of information, but in bursts of information and without the motion blur. Basically it looks 'just' different enough from reality to be disorienting.

But the higher the frame rate, the faster the game is responding to your inputs (controller, mouse movement, keyboard strokes) which makes the game feel more responsive, tho what matters the most is a consistent frame rate, seeing as the response speed is affected by the frames, you dont want to have an ever changing response speed, you want a consistent one, so your brain can adapt and more adequately take your actual actions into the game.
but the difference is if you get a lag spike you wont notice it.  Higher frames means it can drop without affecting how it looks if you get what i mean?

Actually, he did. The eyeball doesn't really have a framerate because doesn't work like a camera. Instead, it receives information continuously, and sends it to the brain to be interpreted. Since it doesn't actually store the visual information as a video, there really is no framerate for the eye itself. However, like he said, there are certain framerates and conditions that can cause headaches when viewed on a screen, but that results from the brain trying to interpret the high framerate video.

Oh and you can always slow down the 30fps ball to 24fps but that's not slowing down much. Most "arty" slomo (such as in music videos) is shot at 120fps and then slowed down to 30 or 24fps. Super slomo shots are captured at 1000fps and above and then slowed down to the native PAL/NTSC format. You need pretty expensive cameras like a Phantom Miro to capture such high frame rates in good resolution and you need lots of good lightening too as the more you push the fps the darker the scene gets.

You can't. You need to convert the 30fps video into a 24fps video which is pretty complicated but most production softwares (like Adobe Premiere Pro, Final Cut) can do it with the press of a button.
This is also why if you record something in NTSC format you can't play it on PAL because of different frame rates the two formats use.

That's for a single lens. The human depth of field comes from binocular vision and how the brain focuses on objects. Try looking at something in front of you and see how much in focus everything in front and behind the object is. You'll notice your brain only focuses on what's in the centre of you visual field.

120fps is good for FPS games where you want sharp detail in the picture so you can see all the enemies firing at you clearly. But if you're watching a movie, you want a more natural looking picture which is close to how we see things in real life.

We see fast moving objects clearly because our eyes can track them and keep them in focus all the time. Reason why movies at 24fps appear very natural to our eyes is because when we see an image, we only see what is in focus (or what our eyes focus on in real life) and rest is a blur (like in real life). When everything on the image is super sharp like in 120fps, our eyes are not used to taking in that much detail, it looks unnatural and gives you a headache!

Actually eyes do have a refresh rate. Cones have a faster refresh rate than rods but its from about 1/10th to 1/50th sec. Which means we can only really see about 60fps.
The fluidity that comes from monitors which are 120hz is more down to how fast and fluidly the monitor is reproducing the image than how fast our eyes see it. 

Also our eyes only have a depth of field of a little over an inch. Which is why when we focus on something, everything else is blury.

What you would experience however is a car hitting you at 60 mph...

And to show the problem with lack of blur on an example, imagine a rotating wheel. If you make an animation with 30 FPS, it's a smooth animation. But if You start rotating the wheel faster and faster, at first it will look indeed like going faster and faster, and then it will just stop (and then go backwards, and stop again). This forces an animator to add a motion blur by himself, and that's hard when doing realistic motion blurs.

It's not that there are higher framerates than we can see. Human eyes don't really have a high limit of how high a framerate we can see, but we do have a lower limit of how low of a framerate can be until we distinguish between individual images instead of a smooth motion. That lower limit is about 20-24fps. By getting higher framerates, it only helps to smooth out motion, which is one reason why videos looks better (there are probably a dozen additional reasons)

Uh, no. The butterzone of 15-25fps represents the point a human eye can see individual images in a video instead of fluent motion. Just b/c a bird has the potential of seeing higher fps doesn't mean time is perceived as being slower; they just have less of a motion blur effect than what we would see, which is very beneficial for predatory birds going at 100mph. A bird views 3secs to be 3, not 30. If birds felt such a large expansion of time they wouldn't be able to do simple things, like hunt.

The problem is video cameras has a high ISO, which means each frame is a shot, and not a continous exposure that captures the blur. It can be fixed by reclrding at a very high fps, AND playing back at the same high fps; our eyes would then be able to blend the frames together and create blur.

It could, but only if your monitor's refresh rate is also high enough, and the game isn't employing any motion blur. With monitors/TVs/whatnot you need to remember that it's not only the frame rate the game or video is rendered at, the refresh rate of the monitor is almost just as important. For example most LCD monitors are 60Hz, meaning they refresh the image 60 times per second, and that's happening whether the game/video is running at 15 fps or 15 000 fps.

Here are some frame rate facts about computers:
Some computer monitors (especially 3D-capable ones) can accept up to 120Hz input, so therefore can truly display 120 FPS (frames per second).

The common assumption that we can't perceive more than 72 FPS is a myth.  Back in the CRT days, there was a noticeable improvement from 85Hz to 120Hz.  Any fast moving objects across the screen are much smoother at 120.  Just moving the cursor in a circle will make it painfully obvious to anyone.

Here are some framerate facts about HDTVs:
Blu-ray movies are 24 FPS (frames per second) because that is what film is.
Broadcast HDTV is 30 FPS.
The input on your TV maxes out at 60 FPS, and you can get that from console games.
Any 120Hz or 240Hz, etc. spec on your TV is internal.  It's taking (at most) 60 FPS and adding transition frames.

The continuous stream of photons and information is correct, but the maximum rate of change a person's eyes can see is measurable.

I conducted a test using a blinking LED. The LED cycles on and off at different rates lognormal-randomly selected between 25Hz and 200Hz, the test taker would simple register if they could see the LED changing or not, they did 25 different rates.

Result: viewing the LED with the retina's cones the average rate was 42Hz (42FPS), while a person's rods could see 59Hz.

Experiment have shown that the faster the frame rate the better the picture until you reach the point of diminishing returns at 72f/s. And fast fame rates DO NOT cause headaches.
Showsacan system was developed for shooting and projection of film at 72 f/s but unfortunately it is used only on amusement park rides
Slowly new standard of probably 60f/s is emerging - James Cameron is shooting Avatar 2 at 60 f/s
Peter Jackson is shooting the Hobbit at 48 f/s.I think the old 24f/s standard is history

I think there is some info in the video that might not be true. No TV cable or broadcast programs in the world is shown in faster than 30 f/s. Japan experiments with 60, but is only an alpha stage. The new HD TV have a screen refreshment rate but which they flash the same frame couple of time. So if the refreshment rate is 240 Hz the TV will flash the same frame of 30f/s broadcast 6 times. They make this to make it appear sharper and to reduce headaches not increase them.
@rudydelapena This happens because old cameras couldn't take pictures to make video as fast as they can now. Everything looks faster because more time was on between the pictures that were taken.

@blackrack2008 No.. It's either 25fps/29.97fps/30fps/60fps which kinda translates to hz, so if you're watching 30fps on a 200hz TV you're only getting 30 REAL IMAGES and 170 FAKE images. (Fake images = black images or duplications of the previous image) By adding black images or showing the previous images twice (or more) and adding a black frame inbetween each it tricks your eyes and makes everything look smoother. So they have 1000hz screens, but they're just gimmicks. :)

@timramich To add to the 3D comments, it's also mainly from when images are flip-flopped.  Say 60 Hz for 30 FPS, every other frame for opposing eyes.  Your brain has to deal with one eye being black while the other shows an image, and make sense of that.  It works because of persistence of vision, but it's totally not ideal.  The polarization method is much friendlier as each is continuously showed an image, and they change at the same time.

Haha 1000 frames per second?  What's he smoking?  Lack of motion blur has nothing to do with headaches.  Your eyes/brain will make the motion blur on its own.  People get headaches, from 3D, not 2D.  The headaches come from the eyes trying to focus on 3 dimensions that aren't there.  It's strain.  People can get nauseous from 2D stuff if it has high frame rates and high resolution, because it looks real, and they get motion sickness.

Does this mean that theoretically there is, or soon will be, more content on Youtube than there has been human existance?
1 hour = 60 minutes.
= 48 hours of content multiplied by 60
2880 hours of content uploaded an hour.
Times by 24 = 69120 hours of content. That's in one day.
Times by 7 = 483840 hours of content uploaded per week.
Times by 52 = 25159680 hours of content uploaded in a year.
That's 2872 YEARS of content uploaded each year. And youtube is getting bigger.

This means the eye is not showing us individual frames but instead the combination of the most recent frames creating Higher resolution with the same number of detectors.

If motion blur is a feature of your brain (not the object itself), and if the eye+brain can't define frames faster than 15 fps whether they are still images or a flowing motion, why would a 60 or 240 fps video cause an headache?

The TV broadcast is not connected directly to your brain, you still look at it with your eyes. So if the final display is at 60 fps, your brain should create a motion blur of every (60/15=)4 frames displayed. If it is at 240fps, then there is 16 frames to blur (better).

@SubGumny  Fast programs (like tennis) are sometimes shot at 1000 fps so that the networks can cut to non-blurred slomo right away. On TV these programs are converted to what your TV can show (e.g. 60 fps or 240fps) but the lack of motion blur is evident. This confuses our brain b/c it expects a continuous but blurry fast object and instead sees a clear object displayed not continuously (like our retinas see in the real world), but rather a bunch of nice clear frames at a rate like 60 fps.

The human eye sees 29 - 31 frames per second at normal heart beat rate. When human we are in danger or doing some extreme sport out heart pumps and a part in our brain triggers and we can see at 60 frames per second to take in more information and make quick decisions. As for the TV thing, The camera may record at 1000 frames + but average Live Television shows show at 29 frames per second. Maybe on a HD dvd it can reach higher frames but not normal tv.

This is why I always find it funny when people complain about their game not running more than 30-60fps, as if it realy matters, that is where synchronization comes in.
Movies are 24fps, but each frame is shown 3 times, so actually 72fps.
Some say, for a game to look great it (the game) HAS to produce 72fps.
That was maybe the case back in the day, but nowadays with the blur, synchronization, etc, that the video card has, does it realy matter.
